Now, what did you make of this McCain ad which aims to draw a comparison between Obama and Paris Hilton and Britney Spears?
Will people buy that?
Well, I suspect not.
I mean, I don't think it's a very good ad.
I mean, it's not, you know, incorrect or factually inaccurate, per se, but it strikes me as a stretch.
I mean, you start out with these comments about being a celebrity and not really having any substance, and then you move into a discussion about oil and Obama's views on that.

It's not a very effective ad, and what it reminds me of a little bit - and I want to stress the word little - is the ad actually that was aired here in Tennessee which used a blond women to try to attack Congressman Harold Ford in his bid for the Senate.
I don't it's any accident that Paris Hilton and Britney Spears were in this ad, two young, blond women.
Yeah.
And what I was struck by when I looked at these ads was that they're almost sort of subliminal.

In other words, if people haven't seen these ads, it's hard to explain, but the images of Spears and Hilton sort of flash by in between pictures of Barack Obama speaking before this massive crowd in Berlin.
And I was, you know - I don't know.
You've analyzed these kinds of ads.
What is the purpose of that kind of tactic?

I mean, I think it's an effort - the McCain campaign is struggling with a way to express their concerns about Barack Obama's experience and lack of substance.

Well, actually, that's a reasonably common tactic, at least over the last 20 years.

The first person to do that at the presidential level was Michael Dukakis, who was very upset about some of the ads that Senior Bush was running in 1988, and he then ran ads attacking the ads that were being aired against him.
So, that's common, and it's happened by, you know, other candidates as well at the presidential level.
I don't think this ad is particularly inspired either.

But it's, you know, it's just common to try to deal with this, to try to knock McCain off his game, because he's trying to be somebody who's above partisan politics, who's truly bipartisan, but yet he's firing off these attacks.
And so the Obama people, maybe correctly, think that this will be an effective tactic.
I just don't think the ad itself is all that, you know, unique or special.
Well, is there any danger in repeating your opponent's message even if the point of repeating is to refute it?
Well, it's - I mean, there's a potential risk there, but you're also labeling it as dirty politics, as negative, as nasty, and the public reacts to that.
We have pretty clear evidence that if you tell people something's negative, they react a little differently to it.

Well, there are a couple of very sound observations there.
I mean, first of all, the negative ads overstate the negative, and so, it pushes the - you know, the candidates seem much more ridiculous than they really are.
Of course, the flip side is that if you take the positive ads, they're way overselling the positive aspects, and so the answer lies somewhere in between.

What the real question that we as political scientists don't have a really good handle on yet is, do ads - let's say, a lot of negative ads - affect a candidate's - whoever wins that race - ability to govern after the election?
A few people have looked at that, and the answer seems to be basically a favorable one, but we haven't studied it as effectively as we could.
